concept.name: Product Vision
concept.definition: A clear, inspiring, long-term goal that describes the future state the product aims to create, typically spanning 2-10 years, providing strategic context for daily development decisions.
concept.purpose: To inspire and align the team around a common future state, guide strategic decisions, and communicate the product's overarching purpose to stakeholders.

characteristics.clarity: Simple enough for all team members to understand and remember
characteristics.stability: Should remain relatively stable, not change quarterly

components.description: Change or transformation to be created

good.vision: Empower developers to create specs 10x faster with knowledge-driven templates
good.analysis: Clear WHO (developers), WHAT (10x faster), HOW (knowledge-driven templates)

good.vision: To be Earth's most customer-centric company
A computer on every desk and in every home
good.source: Microsoft early vision (via Moore, Crossing the Chasm)

bad.vision: Build the best product management tool

sources.author: Cagan, Marty
sources.title: Inspired: How to Create Tech Products Customers Love
sources.key_quote: The product vision describes the future we are trying to create, typically 2-10 years out. The purpose is to provide the team with the context for the daily work they're doing.

sources.author: Pichler, Roman
sources.title: The Product Vision Board
sources.description: Visual framework structuring vision into Vision, Target Group, Needs, Product, and Business Goals

sources.author: Cagan, Marty
sources.title: Product Vision
sources.description: Article on characteristics of effective product visions

validation_rules.description: Vision statement should be 1-2 sentences (max 200 words)
Vision should imply long-term timeframe (2-10 years), not quarterly goals
Vision should be understandable by all team members, not jargon-heavy

anti_patterns.description: Vision is just a list of features ('We will have X, Y, Z')
anti_patterns.problem: Not inspiring, too tactical, lacks strategic context

anti_patterns.description: Vision is just a business metric ('Increase revenue by X%')
anti_patterns.problem: Doesn't inspire team, focuses on company benefit not customer transformation

creation_process: 2. Identify the transformation or change product will create
3. Draft vision statement (WHO, WHAT, HOW, WHY)
4. Validate with stakeholders (is it inspiring? clear?)
communication_tips: Repeat vision in every team meeting
Connect daily work back to vision ('This task helps us achieve X because...')
Use vision in hiring (attract people aligned with mission)
implementation_guidelines.evolution: Vision should evolve slowly (every 2-5 years as market/technology shifts), not change with every pivot or feature release
